div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOW THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1907.

div.head: EXPERIMENTS ON HUMAN BEINGS.
div.p: Some noteworthy evidence, of « rather special kind, was given before the Royal Commission on Vivisection by Mr. G. H. Barford, M.B" says the "Yorkshire Poser."

"Appearing nominally as a representative of the World League of Opponents of Vivisection, Mr. Burfurd confessed that be knew very little about the League or its opinions. He came forward at the request of a friend who is a member, but he himself belongs to no antivivisectional: body, and, his object was to express the views of medical men Practising bomampathy in Great Britain and America He believes, however, that the League agrees

"'The homoeopathic method' of investigating the remedial value of drugs is to try them on healthy human beings—healthy in order that the vitiating result of sickness may be eliminated, baman beeause the major part of s i bomen beings, conscious because the subjective and mental! conditions unattainsble on experiments on animals may be added to the Gudings. The 'experimenters' — always voluntary — are in many instances medical men and women. The drag for investigation is takeu first in very small doses, then in larger and repeated doses, the experiment covering sometimes « long period. A great number of such experiments have been made... .

"Mr. Burford admitted that osefal know. ledge has been obtained by experiments on animals, but maintained as regards drogs that the knowledge would be b-tter andmore completely ubtained by the other method 'A man kuows exactly what are the nécessary limitations when he operates on the haman body. He bas some preliminary knowledge to tell hiai whether his proposed experiment is a fiat defiance of what nature can bear or not. If he was simp y skilled in experimenting on animals he would not koow the exact tax he proposed to levy on the human economy. . . . When you have dea't with animals syou have to deal afterwards with human beings, and thus you have to deal with different tisgues. It is better to go to the human being at once.'

'When asked for « practical proposal for the amendment of the law, Mr. Burford said he main suggestion he would make was that experimeuts with regard to the remedial action of drugs should in the first instance be carried out on healthy boman beings, and that any point left undecided in the experiments on buman beings might then be considered possibly (I say possibly) as @ fit and proper subject fur experimentation on animals.'

Sir Mackenzie Chalmers asked whether he would have it enacted that a licence should not be granted for an experiment vpon an animal antil a corresponding experiment bad been made on a healthy human being He replied that he would leave discretion to the inspector, and thatthe Home Office should be required to give specific reasons in each case why the prior investigation on a human being was not adopted.

"This did not seem to strike the Cotmmissioners as avery practical proposal, but Mr. Burford said he thought it would be found that in the interest of science a sufficient supply of healthy haman beings would be forthoouming. Whatever may be said of Mr. Bartotd's views, they are at least more helpfol than some satirical suggestions made by the Rev. J Page Hopps, in a pamphlet sent to the Commissioners, that experiments should be made on criminals apd intending suitides, instead of on animals—snggestions which were justly characterised by Lord Justice PiéteherMoulton, in his evidence, as 'loathsome levity.' "

div.head: The Luxor Season.
div.p: The Laxor Winter Palace Hotel opened its doors for the season yesterday. There are al- ready a good o-mber of people announced acd there is every reason to believe that we shall bave a good tourist season this year. The weather at present in Laxor is beautiful.

div.head: The Cairo Season. 7
div.p: 'Lhe band ..f the Scotish Borderers played on the terrace of Shepbeard's Hotel on Saturday afternoon, this being the first terrace concert of the season. A sma!l orchestra has been engaged by the Hotel and will play all the evening during the month of November, until the ar rivalvof the regular band frum Europe.

div.head: King Emmanuel's Birthday.
div.p: To-day being the 88th anniversary of the birthday of King Victor Emmanuel figs were floated above all the Consulates of Alexandria and the large houses of the town. The reception held by Marquis di Soragna was attended by the Consular Corps and the élite of the Alexandria Italian community.

div.head: Ports and Lights.
div.p: On Saturday next the Crimi:al Court of Alexandria will hear the cases brought by the Ports and Lighthouses Administrations against certain of their ewployé¢s and officials accused of bribery and corruption. , Socrates Bey Spiro, against whom ao important charge is made, remains in Europe, but we uaderst nd that be will be tried tm absent-a.

div.head: The 'Sphinx"
div.p: Our Cairo contemporary the "Sphinx" hopes to igsue its first number of the season at the ~ @d of the current month. Intending adver- tisers are asked to book space nut later than the 20th, as there is a large demand and disap- pointment may otherwise result. Applications should be addressed to the Manager, Khedivial Buildings, Sharia Bo: lac, Cairo.

div.head: Cairo Scientific Society
div.p: A Meeting of the Society will be held at the School of Medicine, Kasr el Ainy, at 430 o'clock on Thursday next, the 14th November, when the following papers will be read : Dr. G Elliot Smith ras. "Some N. tes on Mummies." Dr. W. A. Schmidt. "The prepara- tion of muscleproteid antisera and their u-e in differentiating meats and meat products in thé practice ot hygiene."

div.head: A Stabbing Affray.
div.p: A stabbing affray occurredin the Sharia Clot Bey on Fridav night es the result of an alleged inesalt. It appears that a Greek was sitting at « café, and an Italian in pa-sing stambled over the former'sout-stretched fuot. The! talian refusing to believe that the action was not inten- tional. Words ensued which led to the Italian stabbing the Greek with his knife. The injaries are reported to be only slight.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre
div.p: "La Signora dalle Camelie" given l»st night at this theatre was a great success for the Italian Dramatic Company. Gemma Caimmi. is well-known and little need to be said as to her dramatic quality Sufficient t» say that she displayed in an extraordinary manver the part of Margherita By her quiet, but most effect. ive acting the peculiarly nervous, hysterical side of the p-rt of Margherita, Siynora Caimmi gave the piece great dramatic significance and brought out the fu | mraning of Dumas. Signor Berti was well appreciated in the part of Armando.

div.head: Belle vue Terrace.
div.p: The Belle Vue Terrace was last evening the scene of an entertainment rather unique and certainly interesting. This consisted of an "International ladies-wrestling watch" and the way in which some seven members of the "weaker" sex acquitted them-elves proved a great surpride to many of the specrators pre sent, mingled perhaps with a little jealousy. The other items on the programme were Mr Lam), a ventriloquist, Mr. Kikuda a Japanese juguler and Mile Eulalia, a slack wire walker, each performance being goed in its way. The Bohemian orchestra under the direction of Karl Koffmann c mtribs ted some well chosen selections during the evening.

div.head: The Savoy Palace.
div.p: The Savoy Palace Hotel of Alexandria js fast establishing for itself a reputation equiva. lent to the moat select hotels of Cairo. In the Savoy, indeed, we have an hotel which ca vie with any, and we are sure that under the abie management of Mr. George Brey, whose popularity among hotel frequenters is great, success is guaranteed. Its cuisine is of the highest order, it is fitted up in a most lnxu- rious manner, unknown in Alexandria prior to the opening of the Savoy, and such are its general merits, that it receives the most no table members: of the many cominunities of Eyypt visiting or residing in Alexandria. The visitors tu the hotel during the past week, and many of whom are at present residing there, 'include Mr. P. W. Machel!, Mr. Harvey, Count and Co ntess Wachtmeister, Moheb Paxha, Mr. Alexander Powell, Mr. and Mrs Walter FP Sarjeait, Mr. Eustratiadis, Mr. Speaker, M. Buubdry, Mr. and Mrs Beyerlé, Mr. Gibbs, Mr., Mrs and Miss Nicholidis, Mr. Rolin, Mr. de Luc, Abdel Kabr Bey, Mr. Gorran, Miss Viedimir, ' r. Teher, Mr. Moneri, Mr. Dima- ropoulo, Me Marrandis, Mr. Tilche, Mr. Pis cher, Mrs. Ruger, Mr. Matzaros, Mr. Hollw-an, and Mr. and Mrs. Talek. Tho-e who have reserved apartments and rooms and are ex: pected to arrive shortly include Viscount and Viscountess Finaree, Mr. and Mrs. Schmidt, Messts. A and D. Proost, Mr. and Mrs. Hoghapfel, aod Mr. and Mre. A. O. Millet.

div.head:
LORD CROMER'S REGIME.
THE PREMIER'S EULOGY.
div.p: London, Monday. The Mansion House speeches were devoid of especial interest. Sir Henry Campbell-Ban- nerman ih eulogising Lord Cromer's regime said that his services not only lifted Egypt from misery and bankrnptey to 'Prosperity, but by his pradence end restraint he had, by avo'ding complications in difficult times, saved this country intense anxiety and great ex- pense.

div.head:
THE AMERICAN SITUATION.
STRAIN ON THE BANKS.
div.p: London, Monday. The Awerican 'situation is still critical and the bank statement the worst on record, thirteen million dollars being notified in deficit.

div.head:
HIS MAJESTY'S BIRTHDAY.
REVIEWS OF TROOPS.
div.p: As briefly annonneced in our Saturday's issue, hix Maj sty's birthday was duly celebrated in iro on the morning of the 9th, when a view ofthe British troops which are stationed in the town was held at the Abdin Square, the regiments taking part consisting of the King's Royal Rifle«, O :idstream Guards, King's Own Sen'tish Borderers, [nniskilling Failiers, and "a" Battery of the Royal Horse Artillery.

The event may this year be said to have opened the yinter season, for in addition to there being A distinct foretaste of the coming cold weather in theair, there were a large number of visitors prexent among the crowds which had assembled to witness thé review long beiore the time at which it bad been advertised to start.

The troops began to-arrive at about a quarter to nine, apd in half an hour all were in their places, and the scene was a most Lrilliant one, the bright auiforms ot the officers nd mev against the background of manitold colours in which the spectators, European and mative, were clothed producing a wonderfully nimated scene in the sunlit square.

At ninethirty the men were called to atte:tion, and a moment later Sir Eldon Gorst drove up escorté! by a guard and accompanied by officials from the gency, the Royal Stan- dard being ren up as he entered the square, nd the mussed troops presenting arms; as the Royal Salute wasgiven the strains of Gol Save the King borst forth from the band.

A general inspection of the troops then follow- d, the Conaul General driving slowly round the square escorted by the General command- ing, and on 'his retarn to the stand three cheers for his Majesty were given by the a-sembled troops and the displxy commenced, the troops passing the stand in review order, the band of ench regiment wheeling off to the opposite side of the square after passing the stand, and there continuing to play autil the next band had come into po-ition.

The men acquitted themselves well in the display which tollowed, and we are gled to be able to repeat that the vef.rtanate accident which subsequently occurred when oneof the horses of the' Artillery came down with its rider, just after the stand hdd been passed during the gallop past, was not as serious as was first imagined, the men teing simply stunned ad bruised by the fall.

The review concluded by the troops ad- vancing fo the centre of the square when once more the Royal Salute was given andGod save the King again played, Sir Eldon Gorst driving off immediately afterwards.

The police arrangements for dealing with the large crow' which attended were ex- cellent and hot the slightest bitch occurred throughout the proceedings, a circumstance which goes far to heighten success on such occasions as this.
In the evening Lady Gorst beld a crowded reception in honour of the occasion, all the notables of Cairo being pres~nt.
A spectator sends the fol uwig account of the para'le of troops at Alexandria :—

The 66th Birthday of His Most Gra-ious Majesty King Edward Vilth was celebrated on Saturday by a parade of the British troops on the Polo Ground at the Spurting.Club. The ground was kept by detachments of the Mili- tary Mounted Police and the Royal Dublin Fusiliers. The 2nd Battalion Ruyal Inniskilling Fusiliers under Col. R. C. Cox was drawn up in line facing North and the spectators were accommodated with chairs near the saluting base. Punctually at 11.15 Col. Cox gave the command "Royal Salute." The Royal Standard was unfurled at the saluting point and the troops saluted, qgo'ours lowered and band playing "God Save the King." Col. Cox ac- companied by his staff officer, Lieut. Wakelin ASC., rode to the saluting point, where G. B. Gould Esq, L.8.0., His Majesty's Consul General, accompanied by Rear Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield. K C M.G., joined him and the troops marched past. After this began the stately ceremouy of "Trooping the C-lor, which was splendidly-done, the fine Band of the regiment playing suitable music. At 12 o'clock the troops reformed line, and gave three cheers for the Kinz, while 21 guns were fired by the Royal Garrison Artillery at Kom el ik. 'this brought the ceremony to a dose. The «pectaturs included all the offieers of the garrixon not on duty, most of the English residents and also the Consuls and Vice Qonsuls of the other powers.

div.head: SATURDAY'S AMATEUR MEETING.
div.p: A very succesful little meeting, was the genral verdict. The amateur element certainly adds to the interest ot race-gvers in Cairo. They watch the gallops or know racing hor-es from the but at an amateur meeting they have perhaps seen the ponies on the polo ground and know the jockey, and therefore naturally take a keen interest.

The attendance, considering that the season can hard'y be considered to have begun, was decide 'ly good, and although there were no very exciting finishes, all the races were fall of interest 'he weather was kind to us, and the Inniskilling Dragoon Band, ably conducted by Major Price, added to the attractions of the afternoon.

For the first race Vanitas was made favourite but Mr. Burwbams Angelo, with Mr. Spierup, won confortably. One of the features of the meeting was Mr. Schreibér's success, winning 2 races with Mulberry and riding the winner, Arbagi, in the last race. We offer him our sincere congratulations. The last win was most popular, Major Ponsonby, the sporting owner, having pursued ( success- folly) an Arabeya, some few weeks » Ago, extracted the puny (we believe with the con- sent of the driver) trained him him-elf and won in gallant fasbion the "Novices Stakes". If the pony was a novice we ventare to think the owner was not. We hear the entry was made in Major Ponsonby's name only, so we presume the late owver has retained no racing interests in the pony. Major Protheroe Smith, who has not had the be-t of | ok lately, is to be congratulated on his win in the Hurdle race, Petrone ruruing well throughout. This was @ pretty race as all five of the horses which tarned out were greys In the Polo Handicap White Wings galloped in very good form; his owner Capt Dunbar we bear comes out gain his season and will swell the ranks of our geod polo players.
Our next race meeting is on the 22nd November and we look furward to some in- teresting racing.

div.head:
FOOTBALL.
VICTORIA COLLEGE v. E.T.C.
div.p: ~ A football match was played, Saturday lest, November 9th between Victoria College and the Eastern Telegraph Co XI on the School ground which ended in a win for the School, six goals to one. Everybody on the home side played well, and for the Telegraph, Prosser, Hay, Shepheard and Eden, the last named, scoring the goal for hisside. . Next Saturday the School boys, only, play a second eleven of Saint Andrew FootbalL Club.

div.p: Last Saturday the competition for anew short rifle, presented tothe elub by Mr. W..B. Moss, of Liverpool took place, concurrently with the shoot for 6 N.R.A. "skilled shot" badges. div.head: MUSICAL AND DRAMATIC SOCIETY
div.p: To The Editor of The "Egyptian Gazette"

I noticed » few days ago in your esteemed paper, a note to the effect that an Amatenr Dramatic 8ociety was about to be formed in Cairo. Now as there is already the "Cabo Musical and Dramatic Society" already formed, which has upon several occasions been to tbe front for obsritsble purposes, notably tbe Calabria earthquake of 1905 and as this is under distinguished patronage it appears to me that the attempted formation of another society, will be inoongruons and poeeibly cause ooo fusion. I will feel moob obliged, if you will insert a notice, pointing out that tbe Cairo Musical and Dramatic Sooiety is in existence
With thanks in anticipation.
I am, yours truly,
J. W. Corodov,
Difctor
Cairo Musical and Dramatic Society

div.head: HORTICULTURE IN EGYPT.
div.p: To The Editor of The "Egyptian Gazette"
Sir,—The courteous communications from your correspondents merit a reply.
The idea of giving prizes for well kept gardens ha- often been discussed by the Committee but baa hot been retried out because of the many difficulties the question presents.
(1) How to divide the small gardens and the largo In England, snob prism are generally limited to cottage gardens and allotments, the judging of which is a comparatively simple matter

(2) When should the competition take place. If warning given, the garden would be specially prepared and cleaned and would not present the general appearance that it does throughout the year A garden thus made ready for the visit of the judges would reflect no credit on the gardener On the other band, a visit without warning might be inconvenient to the owner.
(3) It might induce people to be satisfied with these prizes and not exhibit at the shows held by the society.

(4) The gardens are private, whereas the shows are public. Prizes given to gardens might be a satisfaction to owners, but would do no good to the public who could not visit the gardens which the judges would decide were the beet kept in Alexandria or the neighbor hood Consequently the public could learn no lessons resulting from such decisions

These are the reasons that have up to now prevented the Committee from giving garden prizes but this matter will be discussed again and if any reasonable scheme can be devised the member of the Horticultural Society will be informed.—I am, etc

div.p: The Khedive will leave Alexandria station for Cairo on Monday next at 7.30 am. and his Highness will be f-llowed by the Khedivab, who will leave Montazah at 7.40. His High- ness's: Chief Mater of Ceremonies left Alex- andria yesterday for the capital.

Milling—Dnring the month the 10-stamp mill trested 1,056 tons of ore, which yielded 450 19'dzs find' old, exclaxive of 2 tons of concentrates of an assay value of 82.4dwts per toa. This recovery of 450.18 ots fine gold inc!ades 110.61 ozs recovered by steaming the plates. The ore crushed was derived as follows :—Development, 54 tons ; stopes, 901 tons; damps, 101 tons — 1,056 tons The health of the camp continues good. div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."

One of the surest signs of kidney trouble is dropsical swelling of the limbs and feet or the eyes, neuralgia, rheumatism, sciatica, languor, dizziness, sleeplessness, 'bad blood, pimples on face, heart trouble. div.head:
PREMIER AT THE GUILDHALL.
PRAISE OF LORD CROMER.

THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
THE CONGO SITUATION.

div.p: Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman, speaking at the Guildball, referred to Lord Cromer whose great services have lifted Egypt from bankreptey to prosperity and saved Great Britain from strain, anxiety and expense.

He admitted that he was diappointed with the results of the Hague Conference but he emphasised that the British delegates were speaking for the nation and nourishing no aggressive designs He hoped that the day would come for the cessation of the ruinous race for armaments which was the scourge of our common civilisation.

Regarding the Congo, he said he must speak with great reserve because the Belgian Parlia- ment was shortly to consider the question of annexation. The Government did not intend to interfere, but was deeply impressed with the responsibility _which it shared with other powers regarding th s ma' ter.
He cordially weloomed the German Bmperor and hoped that he would be speedily restored to health in Englands comparatively genial climate. ( Reuter)

div.head:
PRICE OF BREAD.
DISTRESS PROVOKES RIOTS.

div.p: The economic distress and the bigh price of bread has caused serions riots. In Aleppo the mob pillaged the bakeries and floar mills : troops restored order : 8 rioters were wounded. The mob at Beirut hell a demonstration againet the export of flour which was there upon probibited. ( Reuter)

div.head:
GERMAN CROWN PRINCESS.
BIRTH OF A SON.

div.p: The Crown Princess has been safely delivered of a son ( Reuter )
The Crown Princess has given birth to a son. ( Havas)
The German Emperor left this morning for Spithead. There is a thick fog iv the Channel. (Reuter)
The Emperor William's yacht bas anchored at Selsey Bill fog bound. ( Reuter )

In spite of an occasional jarring note the general tone of the German press comments on the Emperor's visit is decidedly friendly. » Opinions differ as to the political significance of the visit, but the desire is manifested that it should prove the opinion of a mew era in Anglo German relations. ( Reuter )
Deputy Bertoloni has been appointed Public Works Minister. ( Havae)

The Emperor has accepted the resignation of Messrs: d'Auersperg, Fuert, Pacak, and Prade. The following are appointed Mipisters Deputies Fredler of commerce, Ebenhoch of agriculture, Gessman, Pescka anil Praschek without portefeuille. (Havas )

div.head:
THE CULLINAN DIAMOND.
PRESENTED TO THE KING.

div.p: Sir, R. 'Solomon has taken the Cullinan Diamond to Sandringham and presented it to the King to-day. (Reuter)

Owing to the unwillingness of the banks to release currency the practice of paying wages and salaries by cheques instead of in cash is becoming widely extended, to the detriment of wage earners, as cheques are only cashable at 1 discount.
America ap to the present has engaged 51,000,000 dollars of gold from Europe. ( Reuter )
M. Pichon announces that the situation in Morocco permits of the withdrawal of the destroyers and 4 cruisers.
M. Regnault has obtained from the Sultan all guarantees of the faithful exeention of the frontier agreements. ( Reuter)
Moroceo being tranquil the destroyers and four cruisers are returning to France. (Havas)
The ex Minister Gianturco is dead. ( Havas)
Signor Gianturoo is dead. ( Reuter)
Lord Kilmaine committed suicide here by jumping from a hotel window and fracturing his skull. ( Reuter )
Lord Chesham broke his neck whilst hunting at Betchley. ( Reuter)
A new case of spying has been detected ; five arrests have been. It is supposed to be connected with the international organisation of spying on the littoral revealed by the Ullmo Case. (Havas)
A suspected case of plague has been notified. ( Havas)

div.head: AN OSTRICH FARM
div.p: The Rev J. F. Hardy contributes the following Iuteating article to the "Queen":

Sensible girls end women are aware that fine feathers do not make fine birds, but still they may like to know something of the home life of the great creatures that furnish feathers for This I can tell them, fr! have visited several times a large ostrich farm « Matariya, near Cairo. At. my Jest visit an American girl was in the party, and we were all amused at the way the the birds looked at the ostrich feathers in bet that, and still more so when an ostrich put his head over the bars of his enclousure and gave her what was perhaps a reproving pat on the hat with his beak or a request to return its property to the ostrich world.

Certainly many young, and even elderly, women waste far too much money spon fea thers. It has been calculated that 'members of the Church of England spend as much each year upon feather« for supposed personal adorn- ment as upon foreign missions, Yeung women belongiaig Reni costermonger business and factory girls aresaidt- for buying ostrich ever, when girls try to as some have at the ostrich On one or two occasions they have to pluck feathers from birds passing being severely bittén or pecked. It was nearly a case of the biter bitten.

The ostrich farm of which we are now speaking is situated on the desert about eight miles frem Cairo. It consists of the house of the manager and the collection of pens or paddocks in which the ostriches live to pro duce feathers for ladies, whe in many respects aré more bird-witted and less wise than the ostriches themselves. The enclosures, in which are atthe present time 1100 birds, are not roofed, because the warm and practically rainless climate of Egypt readers this unneces- sary. They are of two sises. One is a sort o1 common room, in which young and dnmartied male and female ostriches to the number of from ten to twenty live together. The other kind of enclosure is. much smaller, and is reserved for one mele and one female bird when, at five years of age, they show signs of desiring to set ap house for themselves. In the sapd-floor of this hovse the cock scrapes a shallow bole and invites the ben to lay ia it ber eggs, which she does until they number about adozen. Men husbands might learn « lesson from the fact that the ostrich shares all domestic duties with his wife expect that of laying eggs. Both birds sit in turn on the eggs, relieving each other every three hours as ponctually as if they wore the best watches. It was amusing to see the bh sbhand walking up and down waiting anxiously, or at least conscientiously, for the time to come for him to take his seat on what in Eyypt must be almost as warm as a domesgio hearth.

The Coptic Christians in Egypt, observing the domestic virtues of ostriches, have from very ancient times adorned their churches with real and imitative ostrich eggs. I have seen them in Greek churches tuo. They are intended Bto teach that, as the ostriches, male as well as female, take care of their eggs, so Christ watches over the Church and all its members.

In South Africa incubators are used, but not at the Egyptian ostrich farm. Here it is found that the eggs are more productive when hatched by the birds themselves. "Them big fowl" (as an Irish attendant calls the ostriches) instino- tively know whether or not an egg is fertile. If it is not, they turn it out of their nest, and no matter how often a man may replace it, he finds that it is pot outside the most again. Here is another illustration for who knows better than Christ the productive members of His Church.

Those who, like myself, often visit the ostrich farm near Cairo seem to find the number of baby ostriches the same, and that they are at similar stages of development each visit..Of course, they are different birds, but only their caretakers notice the difference in them. Baby ostriches are fluffy rattle things covered with down and small feathers.

When the ostrich is six months old it has to give a harvest of feathers, which are black and white in the case of the male bird and grey in that of the female. Eight month after this, and each ucee-sive eight month, another crop is really to adorn the hat of a lady of Bulgaria or of a "lidy" of Whitechapel There is no warrant in nature for girls and women wearing feathers at all, but it is particularly unnatural when hats are ad red with ostrich feathers of a green, red, or other color not worn by the bird.

In South Africa the feathers are cut off the birds ; at the Egyptian farm they are plucked. I was told that the latter operation did not burt, but any of my readers who have been plucked in an examination will doubt the statement. Plucking cannot give an ostrich much pleasure when it requires six men with ropes to hold him while it is being done The small! feathers that fall off themselves are col. elected, sown together, and made into boas.

A lady once remarked to me that an ostrich looks foolish from top to bottom, but in reality the bird is me foul. It is generally believed that when pursued he hides his in the sand and imagines that the has because it is no longer seen. Politicians and Ecclesiastics often shut their eyes to facts in this way, but not so the ostrich. Those who, Like my friends at the ostrich farm, have to catch him occasionally for plucking or other purposes know that he is by no means the foolish, Cowardly the maker of metaphors would have us believe. The ostrich cannot be said to give more Kicks than halfpennies, for his feathers bring in much money, has he cos- tainly can give a terrible kick. One of the men at the farm was nearly killed by one lately.

What is the food that nourishes the ostrich and its lovely feather at the Cairo farm. It is given from 2lb. To 8lb. Of beans and bran daily, besides an allowance of clover. The years of an ostrich's life are about as many as that of a man-forty, sixty, eight, or one hundred, ac- cording to the constitution of the bird and the sort of life it lives.

From the earliest times, as we learn from the paintings and reliefs in Egyptian tombs and temples, ostrich feathers. were worn by Royalty, and symbolized truth and justice. How and why they were thought to represent these qualities | have not been able to find out, but wears sure that it will be well for the girls who wear them it they feel under a greater obligation to be true and just in all their dealings. After impacting the ostriches we were asked to go on to the flat roof of the manager's house to see the view, and certainly this Arab mentioned that he himself had two wives living with him. As we gave him a tip for his trouble, we hoped that we were not encouraging polygamy by doing so.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: This week, the old gunnery ship "Cambridge" has been paid off, and Devonport will shortly lose one of its oldest landmarks. The old line of battleship bas beep moved into Key-ham Extension, along with the "Calcutta," which was so long Attached to her. Naval men throughout the Empire will bear of the tate of the old ships with more or less regret for to many the "Cambridge" was a home for longer or shorter periods.

The oldironelad "Hero," which once a familiar figure in Mediterranean waters, has been pre- pared as « target ship for experimental por poses, The turret guns have been left on their mountings to ascertain the effects of shell fire upon them.

The Army Council bas issued a circular notifying that officers who received @xtra regimental promotion into the Northumber- land Pusiliera, Royal Warwickshire Reviment, Lancashire Regiment, and Manchester Regi- ment, the 3rd and 4th battalions of which have since been disbanded, are to be given the option of returning to their former regi- ments in the original positions in relation to the officers of those regiments that they pre viously held. Officers who decide to avail themselves of this opportunity will be refanded the expenses incurred by reason of the necessary change of uniform to a maximum grant of £25.

A War Office circular has just been issued conveying the views of the Army Council in regard to the genera! consideration that should govern the conduct of military rifle ranges in Future years. The general principles, which in the opinion of the Army Council, should guide officers in preparing programmes for rifle meeting are that the competitions should be, as far as possible, drawn up in such away as to eliminate al! conditions which would be impossible or improbable in war, and that the rifles should be used in the same state as it would, be when carried by the soldier in the field, no aids to be employed —such as b/ackened or coloured sights—which are not normally available on active service. In addition, bow- ever, it is considered necessary to formulate more definite principles in order that the best results may be obtained from the energy and ammunition expended at thee rifle meetings. Tt 'is painted out that the attainment of a good average standard of efficiency by a large number of men is infinitely more important than the developing of phenomenal skill by o few champions, of the compilation of "record" scores by competitors who on fine their practice to one form of shooting It is, con- sequently, necessary to suit the condition of each competition to the rank and experience of the competitors so as to avoid the discourage- ment of young soldiers and the dissemination of false ideas as to musketry training. Team competitions at unknown ranges are stated to be the most practicable of all forms of shoot- ing, provided that mistakes in fire direction are notified and penalized before fire is opened. It is considered chat individual competitions at long range have very little value as tests of proficiency with the rifle. The use of bullseye targets should be limited, as a rule, to the elementary competi- tions for young soldiers of under three years service ;and "sighting" shots should be only allowed in rapid firing competition, in which accuracy combined with a high rate of fire, is the first consideration. The value of steady, accurate shooting is to be kept in view as the foundation of skill with the rifle ; but, in formulating the conditions for a championship the param unimportance of time in military conditions for soldiers of three of more years service should never permit as lower rate of fire than three rounds per minute for a serie of shots. It is pointed out that, in slow shooting. the best military abot is probably the man who, in skirmishing, first applies an effective shot to the service target at unknown ranges "Coaching" -- by which term is to be understond the observation of atmospheric conditions by team coach, in order to relieve the firer of that necesity-is not to be allowed. Too much importance is not to be attached, in future to complaints as to unequal conditions of light, and so forth; and in this connection it is point -ed out that the element of chance is accepted, and is regarded as advantageous in many other forms of popular competition.

div.head:
Dr. Le Clerc's
Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.
Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
5 fr. et 2 fr. 50
